article_title: Unionized nurses in Texas and elsewhere not so secret weapon for Sanders campaign
article_text: To continue reading this story, you will need to be a digital subscriber to HoustonChronicle.com.

article_metadata.description: WASHINGTON – With Hillary Clinton's past political experience in Texas, it might seem rash for backers of Bernie Sanders' to voice confidence that the Vermont senator will fare well in the Lone Star State's March 1 presidential primary  [...] along with the committed liberals and young voters, Sanders has one group steadfastly behind him and believing he'll do well across Texas – unionized nurses.  Castro, Rep. Luis Gutierrez, D-Ill., and Dolores Huerta, co-founder of the United Farm Workers, issued a statement through Clinton asserting that Sanders was "on the wrong side of the immigration debate" by voting against an immigration reform bill in 2007.  For Sanders, a trove of 252 Texas delegates - many of which will be apportioned based on the March 1 vote - is appealing, and the campaign has scoffed at the notion that Clinton, polling well in many states, can deliver mortal damage to Sanders' effort in Texas.  The unionized nurses contend they understand America's health system as well as anyone, and they back Sanders because of his embrace of a single-payer health care system, not in spite of it.  Sanders support of single-payer - in which government oversees health insurance rather than private insurers - has proved challenging for Clinton to answer.  Jean Ross, co-president of National Nurses United, argued that what exists in the United States is not a health care system but a medical system based on profit.
article_metadata.author.name: By Bill Lambrecht
